coredata.dc:title: Simulation of an anion in water: effect of ion polarizability
coredata.dc:creator: Karim, Omar A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A polarizable-polar water model is used to study the structure of wate near a chloride ion. A semi-classical description of ion polarizability is included. Significant changes in the solute-solvent distribution functions are observed. When compared with a simulation without ion polarizability, it is found that the hydration number is further decreased when ion polarizability is present.

Introduction The study of ions in aqueous solution is of fun- damental interest and ions in solution also partici- pate in many important chemical and biochemical processes. Computer simulations have been ex- tremely useful in attempts to understand the prop- erties of ionic solutions [l 3]. A variety of potential models have been proposed and used for simulating such systems. Recently it has been recognized that many-body polarization effects must be taken into account to correctly model some of the properties of solutions [4 6]. Polarizable polar models for water and ionic solutions are still in relatively early stages of development, although significant advances have been made [7 11]. While non-polarizable models for water give good structural properties for bulk water, they overestimate, for instance, the hydration number of the chloride ion [12,13]. A desirable po- tential model should preserve many of the properties obtained correctly from non-polarizable models, im- prove the description of properties dependent on many-body effects and also be computationally ef- ficient. The recently proposed Spnk Klein (SK) model [1 4] meets some of these requirements. This empirical model has been shown to give hydration numbers for the chloride ion in accord with exper- iment [151. Ion polarizability was not included in the initial work [15] describing the hydration of the chloride ion. Although no tuning of the ion water potentials was attempted, a good hydration structure was obtained. Ion water cluster calculations [5 8] have led the way to the inclusion of non-additive forces but there have been relatively few studies of ionic solutions with the inclusion of non-additive potentials [16 201. Some of these will be discussed subsequently. In this work we have partially reparametrized the SK model, which leads to an improved prediction of some of the experimentally known properties of liq- uid water. Further, we have included ion polariza- bility into simulations with the model and studied some of the consequences for chloride ion hydration. In section 2 we describe the computer model and the simulation methods, Implementation of a semi-clas- sical model for ion polarizability is discussed. Re- sults are presented and analyzed in section 3, fol- lowed by a discussion in section 4. 2. Model and ion polarizability The SK model used here includes electronic po- larization in thermal equilibrium with the configu- mtional degrees of freedom. While this should be of concern iii studying time-dependent phenomena, it is of less importance in considering equilibrium properties. A cold-polarization version of the SK model has been developed [211, but is computa- tionally more demanding. We have therefore chosen the finite-temperature polarization model for this work. The reparametrized SK model (RSK) does lead to a self-diffusion constant closer to the exper- imentally observed value. However, the result is still about 25% below the experimental value. The pa- rameters for the SK and the RSK model are shown in table 1. Only those parameters which differ for the RSK model are shown. For a complete description of the SK model the reader is referred to the original work [14]. Ion polarizability is modeled by assigning a linear polarizability at the ion center of mass. For imple- mentation with the SK model, it is assumed that the net charge on the chloride ion can be resolved into an effective nuclear charge of + 7e and an electron shell [23] charge of 8e. The nuclear charge is ftxed at the center of mass of the ion. The polarization (shell) charge position is obtained from the value of the electric field vector at the nuclear site and the ion polarizability. The polarization charge (q0) is as- sumed to be harmonically bound to the nuclear site and have zero inertia [24]. Thus, if the local electric field at the nuclear site is E, then the polarization charge position r0 is assigned to r0=a10~E/q0, where r0 is the vector from the nuclear site to the polari- zation charge site. All molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were performed in the NVE ensemble, with periodic boundary conditions. The Verlet [25] algorithm with SHAKE [26], Ewald [27,28] ~ summation and a time step of 2.5 fs was used to in- tegrate to equations of motion for each molecule. Ve- locities were resealed occasionally to obtain the de- sired average temperature. For the bulk water simulations a cubical box of side 18.6 A and 216 molecules was used. Averages were taken over 100 ps after equilibrium. The chloride ion simulation consisted of one anion and 215 water molecules. The anion was introduced by replacing one of the water molecules, with no alteration in the box size. In brief, the following algorithm was used: with a given configuration, the forces on all the sites and the electric field at the chloride center of mass were calculated; the force on the chloride polariza- tion site was transferred to the center of mass; all the particles were moved one time step, consistent with the forces and constraints; a new location for the ion polarization site was found on the basis of the elec- tric field obtained in the first step, and the cycle was repeated. Transferring the force from the polariza- tion site to the center of mass is a good approxi- mation when the separation between the two sites is small [24 J. This is found to be the case. All charge sites interacted with all the other charge sites in the sample, with no truncation, and the Ewald sum [28] (see footnote 1) was used to include long-range forces. The implementation of ion polarizability vi- olates energy conservation, since the ion polariza- bility is treated as a slave to the net field at the center of mass. However, the energy fluctuation is only 3 parts in iO~ and the average energy drift is even smaller. No local thermal effects were observed from monitoring temperatures in different layers of the simulation box. Each sample was equilibrated for 10 ps, and averages were taken from a subsequent 30 Ps simulation. 3. Results 3.1. This is in addition to the de- crease observed due to solvent polarization effects. The effect and importance of including ion polar- izability in a model has been studied in the case of ion water clusters [5 8]. To our knowledge, few studies of ions in dilute solution with the inclusion of many-body forces have been published [16 18]. In these calculations the non-bonded interactions were truncated near 8 A. Truncation of long-range forces can have potentially important consequences regarding the hydration structure of anions [36]. This initial work can be compared with part of a re- cent simulation [17] of ionic solutions where three- body ion water water potentials were employed. In the latter calculation, it was observed that the chlo- ride hydration number is significantly changed when three-body potentials are included. A similar result is obtained here when ion polarizability is included. A decrease in height of the first ion oxygen peak is observed here for the chloride, a feature which seems common to anions and cations [16,17]. The rdfs ob- tained here are qualitatively similar to previous work [17], although there are some quantitative differ- ences. The hydration number for the chloride ion is close to six for both models. In the case of a single ion at least two possible mechanisms, related to ion polarization, can be re- sponsible for decreasing the hydration number. There may be an increased mobility of water molecules be- tween the first and second hydration shells of the ion. This mechanism seems the more likely one for weakly polarizable ions, such as sodium, where polarization of the ion can be expected to play a less direct role in solvation. For strongly polarizable ions such as the chloride, a second mechanism is also possible. The ion will not present a spherically symmetric poten- tial profile to its neighbors due to the induced po- larization. This can act to repel some of the neigh- boring water molecules while attracting others more strongly. As a consequence, one could then expect a shortening of the ion oxygen distance was well as a lowering of the first peak in the rdf. This seems the more likely mechanism for the decrease in hydration number observed here when ion polarizability is in- cluded. Further study in this direction is needed. The average electric field at the polanzability cen- ter of an isolated solvated ion can be expected to vanish. This implies that the average value of the in- duced ion polarization should be zero. In this sim- ulation it was observed that the orientation of the ion dipole moment is long-lived. There is significant correlation over the length of the 30 ps production runs. This fact is not of great concern in the present work, since the temporary locking of the ion po- larization in a particular direction is not significant, there being no preferred direction. However, in the case of a pair of ions the isotropy around the ions is broken, and it will become important that averages be taken over periods of time long enough to allow the ion polarization to relax. This relaxation may oc- cur on the time scale of local solvent configurational relaxation times. We have studied some of the hydration character- istics of the chloride ion where the model includes solvent and solute polarizability, resulting in non- additive effective interactions. Long-range forces 564 Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 were included through Ewald summation and not truncated. The effects of ion polarization are signif- icant in the case of the chloride ion. Open questions remain regarding single ion hydration and dynamics. It would also be interesting to investigate the case of ion pairs [37] in solution.
